t: 2 Samuel 23
David’s Last Words

These*p are the last words of David: “The*pn inspired utterance of David son of Jesse, the*ld utterance of the man exalted by the Most High, the*ln man anointed by the God of Jacob, the*ld hero of Israel’s songs:
“The*pn Spirit of the Lord*s spoke through me; his*ld word was on my tongue.
The*ln God of Israel spoke, the*ld Rock of Israel said to me: ‘When*ln one rules over people in righteousness, when*ld he rules in the fear of God,
he*ln is like the light of morning at sunrise on*ld a cloudless morning, like*ln the brightness after rain that*ld brings grass from the earth.’

“If*pn my house were not right with God, surely*ld he would not have made with me an everlasting covenant, arranged*ld and secured in every part; surely*ln he would not bring to fruition my salvation and*ld grant me my every desire.
But*ln evil men are all to be cast aside like thorns, which*ld are not gathered with the hand.
Whoever*ln touches thorns uses*ld a tool of iron or the shaft of a spear; they*ld are burned up where they lie.”
David’s Mighty Warriors
These*p are the names of David’s mighty warriors: Josheb-Basshebeth,*p a Tahkemonite, was chief of the Three; he raised his spear against eight hundred men, whom he killed in one encounter.

Next*p to him was Eleazar son of Dodai the Ahohite. As one of the three mighty warriors, he was with David when they taunted the Philistines gathered at Pas Dammim for battle. Then the Israelites retreated,

but Eleazar stood his ground and struck down the Philistines till his hand grew tired and froze to the sword. The Lord*s brought about a great victory that day. The troops returned to Eleazar, but only to strip the dead.
Next*p to him was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. When the Philistines banded together at a place where there was a field full of lentils, Israel’s troops fled from them.
But Shammah took his stand in the middle of the field. He defended it and struck the Philistines down, and the Lord*s brought about a great victory.
During*p harvest time, three of the thirty chief warriors came down to David at the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.
At that time David was in the stronghold, and the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem.
David longed for water and said, “Oh, that someone would get me a drink of water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem!”

So the three mighty warriors broke through the Philistine lines, drew water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem and carried it back to David. But he refused to drink it; instead, he poured it out before the Lord.*s

“Far be it from me, Lord,*s to do this!” he said. “Is it not the blood of men who went at the risk of their lives?” And David would not drink it. Such*p were the exploits of the three mighty warriors.
Abishai*p the brother of Joab son of Zeruiah was chief of the Three. He raised his spear against three hundred men, whom he killed, and so he became as famous as the Three.
Was he not held in greater honor than the Three? He became their commander, even though he was not included among them.
Benaiah*p son of Jehoiada, a valiant fighter from Kabzeel, performed great exploits. He struck down Moab’s two mightiest warriors. He also went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion.

And he struck down a huge Egyptian. Although the Egyptian had a spear in his hand, Benaiah went against him with a club. He snatched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.
Such were the exploits of Benaiah son of Jehoiada; he too was as famous as the three mighty warriors.
He was held in greater honor than any of the Thirty, but he was not included among the Three. And David put him in charge of his bodyguard.
Among*pln the Thirty were: Asahel*ld the brother of Joab, Elhanan*ld son of Dodo from Bethlehem,
Shammah*ld the Harodite, Elika*ld the Harodite,
Helez*ld the Paltite, Ira*ld son of Ikkesh from Tekoa,
Abiezer*ld from Anathoth, Sibbekai*ld the Hushathite,
Zalmon*ld the Ahohite, Maharai*ld the Netophathite,
Heled*ld son of Baanah the Netophathite, Ithai*ld son of Ribai from Gibeah in Benjamin,
Benaiah*ld the Pirathonite, Hiddai*ld from the ravines of Gaash,
Abi-Albon*ld the Arbathite, Azmaveth*ld the Barhumite,
Eliahba*ld the Shaalbonite, the*ld sons of Jashen, Jonathan*ld
son of Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam*ld son of Sharar the Hararite,
Eliphelet*ld son of Ahasbai the Maakathite, Eliam*ld son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
Hezro*ld the Carmelite, Paarai*ld the Arbite,
Igal*ld son of Nathan from Zobah, the*ld son of Hagri,
Zelek*ld the Ammonite, Naharai*ld the Beerothite, the armor-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah,
Ira*ld the Ithrite, Gareb*ld the Ithrite
and*ld Uriah the Hittite. There*ln were thirty-seven in all.
